data.title: A must see for Phi Mu and A D Pi women - also interesting for others
data.text:
This is a lovely home with an interesting history and excellent preservation.  
Visited on a recent weekday afternoon with my Phi Mu alumnae group, and really enjoyed it.  Jessie was our guide, and she is fantastic.  The parlors that are devoted to Phi Mu and A D Pi history were the highlight for us, of course, and the reason we visited, but the rest of the home is worth taking in as well.  
Born a Yankee, I found the dining room fascinating - each chair seat depicts the state seal of a different confederate state done in needlepoint - and the chairs are arranged around the room in the order of secession from the Union.  Jessie told us that the local Sidney Lanier chapter of the UDC made them, and often meets there.   And speaking of Sidney Lanier, there is a nice painted portrait of him in the front hall.  He was born in a home nearby.
This home has a nice little gift shop, kitchen building at the back, back garden, and free parking in back which can be accessed from a side street or from a narrow side alley.  Note that you must climb a few stairs to get in and out of the house, and climb a full set of stairs in order to see the upstairs, as there is no elevator.  Admission prices are very reasonable.  I recommend that you plan to spend around 2 hours here.

The historical section of Macon is lovely and has much to see.  What a blessing that the river was flooded which prevented Union troops from burning Macon during the March to the Sea!
I would love to go back and spend a day or two looking around the area.

data.title: An unexpected surprise
data.text: Making our way to Florida while avoiding Matthew, we found ourselves in Macon on Saturday mid afternoon. We only had time for one stop and selected the Cannonball House. Our self guided tour allowed us all the time we wanted to enjoy the historical value of the location. The staff was friendly, knowledgeable & willing to answer any questions. The gift shop had my collection of tree ornaments, which made my day. My only regret is that we didn't have time to enjoy the other local historic sites. Guess we will make our way back to Macon-friendly people & lots to see.

data.title: Don't. Miss this when visiting Macon
data.text: Located a short distance from the more well known Hay House, it is no poor relation, very well,renovated property, excellent guide , Jessie, who really brought the place to life with her knowledge and anecdotes. There is parking down a narrow lane.

data.title: Very informative
data.text: Our guide was very knowledgeable about the history.  She told me things I did not know even after living here over 25 years.

data.title: A walk through history
data.text: The house was interesting and loved to learn about the history of the town and the family has the house got passed down through generations. However I brought my children. They enjoyed it, but I the tour was a little slow for them.

data.title: good tour guide
data.text: Tour guide was very informative.  House has alot of stairs but its nicely decorated for the time period.  Cute gift shop.

data.title: See it with Hay House
data.text:
Macon reminds me of Montgomery, AL in that there is SO much to see and do that you can take two days to really enjoy yourself among the restaurants, pubs, and historic shenanigans. 

The cannonball house is known for a cannonball having gone through it. Now, the hole is said to still be there, but there is not a lot of it you can really see. Other than that, as in most of Georgia's exhibits, the exhibits have some rare and cute acquisitions such as the Civil War Eagle mirror, which in times of war looks one way, and in times of peace looks the other. I have got to own one of those mirrors if it is the last thing I own. 

Great times.

data.title: Great Antebellum House with Even Better Stories
data.text: Honestly it is the stories surrounding this house which make it stand out and worth visiting.  It is named for the cannonball which hit it during the War for Southern Independence.  However, the family stories and those surrounding the two Sororities preserved in the house definitely added to the experience.

data.title: Historic Macon
data.text: Very interesting short tour of Civil War pass through Macon, Ga. and how the house got its name and the history prior and after the Civil War. Small souvenir shop.

data.title: Must see after Hay House
data.text: The Cannonball House is a beautiful house that should be seen after the Hay House.  The Hay House is a showcase whereas the Cannonball House is just as beautiful but more of an actual living home from the 19th century.  The furnishings are stunning as they are original or from the period of the rooms being displayed.  The Cannonball House is so named because of a wayward Civil War shell that damaged the home but did not explode.  Although this is interesting the house and the furnishings are so much more interesting.

data.title: Website needs better management
data.text: We looked up the website the morning we were going to go. THERE WAS NO MENTION OF BEING CLOSED ON APRIL 8! We get there and go around the back where a small note on the back door says we are closed.

data.title: gotta go by and see it even if just once
data.text: i had heard about this home for years before accidentally bumbling across it while lost looking for a place to eat. i bet that made quite an impression on who ever it was that was in that room when she landed. glad they miss the explosion. not really much to see here, but glad to have finally seen it.

data.title: Small, but very interesting.
data.text: Just a few steps down from the Hay House.  Small, but interesting especially with the docent we had.  He had so many stories.  You get a guided tour anytime you show up.  $6 for seniors.

data.title: A telling of  Civil War
data.text: Another amazing old historic Southern Home in Macon.  This home was struck by a cannonball fired from across the river by the Yankees.  Beautiful home and the upstairs has all the civil war memorabilia displayed and yes the cannonball is at the door downstairs. All of these homes are within walking distance and you can sit and rest on the front porches.

data.title: Good stop after the Hay House!
data.text: Walk a few doors down after visiting the MUST SEE HAY HOUSE.  Sit a spell on the front porch and feel like a real Southerner.  Also, after touring the inside, walk around and check out one of the best hidden back yards in all of Macon.  Quiet and charming right in the heart of Downtown Macon.  There really is a cannonball inside the front door so kids are not disappointed but really just a NEAT old home.

data.title: Visit the Civil War Era South
data.text: If you want to get a feel for the Civil War Era South and how the upper middle class lived this is a great opportunity.  Not everything was maintained to the era but you get a pretty good idea of how it was to live in the old South.  In order to see how the ultra rich lived you need to also visit the Hay House which is walking distance from the Cannonball House.  Get there early or you may feel rushed out the door by the staff.

data.title: historical homes in macon ga
data.text: good example of a historical home, includes viewing of where a cannonball hit the house during the civil war, hence the name of the home - also landscaped and much of original architecture inside; cost extra to view the upstairs but can arrange a tour for that

data.title: Good Rainy Day Viewing Before the Hay House.
data.text: A good rainy day place to do before the HAY House that is 1/2 blook away. Has some interesting civil war items and knowledgeable staff.

data.title: More than a Cannonball House.
data.text:
I grew up and livied in Macon most of my life. I never visited this place because the only thing i KNEW ABOUT IT WAS THAT IT WAS FAMOUS FOR BEING STRUCK BY A CANNONBALL FIRED FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE RIVER BY SHERMAN'S TROUPS AS THEY MARCHED TO sAVANNAH. hOWEVER, UPON RETIREMENT WE SET OFF TO SEE ALL THE SIGHTS IN OUR HOMETOWN WE HAD NEVER BEFORE SEEN.
Upstairs is where the true treasure of the cannoball house is. Memorabilia of the War Between The states abounds there, in nearly pristine form, and it is a most educational and historical experience to visit the upstairs and see the many historical treasures there..

data.title: A hidden gem.
data.text: This was a little museum we called into mainly because we wanted to see some civil war history. The house was brilliant! Coming from overseas, it was a great introduction into the history or the southern states during the civil war with some great displays. Also some great information about some strong independent women!
